#### DOCUMENT KE-REG-003
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.centralbank.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/PRUDENTIAL-GUIDELINES.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Prudential Guidelines
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2013 (January)

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Main prudential guidelines for institutions licensed under Banking Act
- Effective date: January 2013
- Guidelines on: Liquidity Coverage Ratio, Net Stable Funding Ratio, Leverage Ratio
- Risk-Based Credit Pricing Model revised
- Banking (Penalties) Regulations 2024 drafted (February 2024) to provide framework for monetary penalties
- Specific prudential guidelines for MFIs and DTMs exist separately

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: These guidelines drive the risk management and reporting requirements that MFI software must support. The 2024 penalties framework indicates CBK is strengthening enforcement.

---

#### DOCUMENT KE-REG-004
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.centralbank.go.ke/images/docs/legislation/GUIDELINE%20ON%20AGENT%20BANKING-CBK%20PG%2015.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Guideline
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2010

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Banking Circular No. 2 of 2010 - Guideline on Agent Banking
- Separate guidelines for DTMs: "Guideline on the Appointment and Operations of Third Party Agents"
- "Guideline on Marketing Offices and Agencies for DTMs"
- Agent banking is critical distribution channel for reaching underserved populations
- Regulations subject banks to requirements, restrictions and guidelines for transparency

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Agent banking is the backbone of financial inclusion in Kenya. MFI software MUST support agent management, commission calculations, float management, and agent transaction tracking. This is non-negotiable functionality.

---

#### DOCUMENT KE-REG-005
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.costofcredit.co.ke/downloads/Centra_%20Bank_of_Kenya_Consumer%20_Protection.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Guideline
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2013 (Updated 2024)

**KEY CONTENT**:
- CBK Prudential Guidelines include CBK/PG/22 on Consumer Protection
- Consumer Definition: Any entity/person who uses/has used/may contemplate using products or services
- Transparency Requirements: All promotional material must be accurate, honest, understandable
- Advice must be objective based on consumer profile considering complexity and risks
- Prohibited Practices: Unconscionable/unreasonable terms, undue influence, disguising material facts
- Institutions must inform customers of ALL charges, fees, penalties
- Consumer Protection Policy Version 3.0 updated September 2024
- Complaint resolution TAT: 7 working days (varies by severity/complexity)

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Consumer protection is increasingly emphasized. MFI software needs transparent fee calculation engines, clear disclosure statements, and robust complaints management systems with automated TAT tracking.

---

#### DOCUMENT KE-REG-006
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.centralbank.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/GUIDANCE-NOTE-ON-CYBERSECURITY-FOR-THE-BANKING-SECTOR.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Guidance Note
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2017 (2024 update)

**KEY CONTENT**:
- CBK Guidance Note on Cybersecurity (August 2017) for banking sector
- Cybersecurity Guideline for Payment Service Providers (July 2019)
- 2024: CBK takes note of Computer Misuse and Cybercrimes (Critical Information Infrastructure and Cybersecurity) Regulations 2024
- CBK Survey on adoption of 2017 Cybersecurity Guidance conducted in 2024
- Assess cyber risk awareness, preparedness, and resilience
- Banks and MFIs must exceed minimum cybersecurity requirements

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Cybersecurity is not optional. MFI software must demonstrate compliance with CBK cybersecurity guidelines. With 2024 national regulations in place, expect increased scrutiny and potential audits. ISO 27001 certification for software vendors will become competitive advantage.

---

#### DOCUMENT KE-REG-007
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.centralbank.go.ke/aml-cft-cpf/
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: AML/CFT Framework
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2009-2024

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Primary legislation: Proceeds of Crime and Anti Money Laundering Act 2009 (POCAMLA)
- Proceeds of Crime and AML Regulations 2013
- Prevention of Terrorism Regulations 2013
- CBK Prudential Guideline: Proceeds of Crime and Anti-Money Laundering (CBK/PG/08)
- Focus areas: Customer Due Diligence (CDD), Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD), Politically Exposed Persons (PEPs), Suspicious Transaction Reports (STRs), AML/CFT/CPF Training, Targeted Financial Sanctions (TFS)
- April 2025: CBK survey on cross-border physical cash movement
- Kenya committed to FATF international standards

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: AML/CFT is table stakes. MFI software must have robust KYC, CDD, EDD, PEP screening, STR filing, and sanctions screening. The 2025 cash movement survey signals CBK is intensifying monitoring.

---

#### DOCUMENT KE-REG-008
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.centralbank.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/Procedures-for-licensing-Digital-Credit-Providers-Revised-October-2024.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Regulatory
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Licensing Procedures
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-10

**KEY CONTENT**:
- Revised October 2024
- Stage 1: Approval of Name (for new entities)
- Stage 2: Application for Licence
- Existing incorporated DCPs start at Stage 2
- Must comply with CBK (Digital Credit Providers) Regulations 2022 Part II
- Application fee: Ksh 5,000 (non-refundable)
- Payment via banker's cheque to CBK, RTGS or other mode specified by CBK
- Directory of Licensed DCPs maintained online

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: The October 2024 update shows active regulatory evolution. Software providers targeting DCP market must stay current with frequent regulatory changes. Low licensing fee encourages market entry.

### SECTION 4: MFI/SACCO SECTOR DATA (6 Documents)

#### DOCUMENT KE-DATA-001
**SOURCE_URL**: https://nairobiwire.com/2024/04/cbk-releases-list-of-licensed-microfinance-banks.html
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Regulatory List
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-04-24

**KEY CONTENT**:
- CBK published list April 24, 2024
- 14 licensed Microfinance Banks in Kenya
- Licensed institutions include:
  1. Faulu Microfinance Bank Limited
  2. Kenya Women Microfinance Bank PLC
  3. Salaam Microfinance Bank Limited
  4. SMEP Microfinance Bank PLC
  5. LOLC Kenya Microfinance Bank PLC
  6. Rafiki Microfinance Bank Limited
  7. Branch Microfinance Bank Limited
  8. Sumac Microfinance Bank Limited
  9. U & I Microfinance Bank Limited
  10. Choice Microfinance Bank Limited
  11. Caritas Microfinance Bank Limited
  12. On It Microfinance Bank Limited
  13. Muungano Microfinance Bank PLC
  14. (One additional not named)
- Market Classification: Large (top 5 hold 83.8% market share), Medium, Small
- Large MFIs: Faulu, Kenya Women, SMEP, Rafiki, Caritas
- Medium MFIs: Branch, Sumac, LOLC, U & I, Muungano, Salaam
- Licensed between 2009-2019

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: Only 14 licensed MFIs, highly concentrated (top 5 = 83.8%). This is a small, oligopolistic market. Sales strategy should prioritize the top 5 for immediate market penetration. The medium tier may be more price-sensitive but collectively represents 16.2% of market.

#### DOCUMENT KE-DATA-002
**SOURCE_URL**: https://saccoreview.co.ke/unpacking-sasra-supervision-report-2024-a-sector-in-resilient-expansion/
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Annual Report
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-09-25

**KEY CONTENT**:
- SASRA SACCO Supervision Annual Report 2024 released September 25, 2025
- Performance year: December 31, 2024
- 357 regulated SACCOs (177 DT-SACCOs, 178 NWDT-SACCOs)
- Total assets: Sh1.08 trillion (10.1% growth, highest in 5 years)
- Membership: 6.84 million (6.57% growth), 30% of Kenya's adult working population
- Gross loans: KSh 845.11 billion (11.41% growth from KSh 758.57B)
- Loans-to-assets ratio: 73.36% (up from 72.66%)
- Loan disbursements: Ksh 542 billion
- Deposits: KSh 749.43 billion (9.86% growth)
- Capital reserves: KSh 197.54 billion (17.55% growth)
- Retained surpluses: KSh 52.66 billion (21.69% growth)
- Dividend payouts: 10.46% (down from 10.92% in 2023) - first decline in 3 years
- NPL ratio: 8.2% (up from 7.5%)
- Top 60 large SACCOs: 77.07% market share (KSh 829.41B assets)
- Kenya ranks 14th globally in SACCO assets (highest in Africa)

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: SACCO sector crossed KSh 1 TRILLION in assets - this is a MASSIVE market. 357 institutions, but 60 large SACCOs control 77%. Rising NPLs (8.2%) signal credit risk challenges where better software could help. The 6.84M membership base represents 30% of adult workers - huge financial inclusion impact.

#### DOCUMENT KE-DATA-003
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.safaricom.co.ke/media-center-landing/press-releases/safaricoms-m-pesa-hits-34-million-customers-in-kenya
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Corporate Announcement
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-12-05

**KEY CONTENT**:
- M-PESA reached 34 million active subscribers in Kenya (November 2024)
- 500,000 new subscribers added Oct-Nov 2024 (1.5% growth)
- Africa-wide: 66.2 million customers (FY ending March 2024)
- Revenue FY2024: Ksh 139.9 billion (19.4% growth from 117.2B)
- M-Pesa contributes 42.4% of Safaricom's total service revenue
- H1 FY2024: M-PESA revenue KSh 77.2B (42.9% of service revenue, 16.6% growth)
- Transaction value: Ksh 40.2 Trillion
- Transaction volume: 28.3 billion
- Lipa Na M-PESA merchant payments: KSh 972.6B from 1.4B transactions (H1 FY2024)
- Agent network: 300,000+ agents nationwide
- Merchants: 1.5 million MSMEs
- Daraja platform: 90,000+ developers, 40,000+ integrations
- Market share: 93.4% (June 2024), down from 97.1% (June 2023)
- M-PESA Ratiba standing orders: 1M+ opt-ins in 1 month, 260,000+ transactions

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: M-Pesa is DOMINANT infrastructure - 34M users, 93.4% market share, KSh 40.2 TRILLION in transactions. Any MFI software that doesn't integrate with M-Pesa is DOA. The Daraja API with 40,000+ integrations shows robust developer ecosystem. M-PESA Ratiba (standing orders) is direct competition to SACCO savings products.

#### DOCUMENT KE-DATA-004
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.cliffedekkerhofmeyr.com/news/publications/2025/Practice/Banking-Finance-Projects/banking-finance-and-projects-alert-3-April-kenyas-rising-bad-loans-a-closer-look
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Banking Report
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-12

**KEY CONTENT**:
- December 2024 NPL ratio: 16.4% (highest in decade)
- NPL ratio progression: 14.8% (Dec 2023) → 15.5% (Feb 2024) → 15.6% (Dec 2023) → 17.1% (Dec 2024)
- Total bad loans: Sh728.5 billion (10.8% growth from Sh657.7B in June 2024)
- Q2 2025 NPL ratio: 17.6%, then eased to 17.1% (Sept 2025)
- Worst affected sectors: Agriculture (20% NPL), Real Estate (18%)
- Other affected: Personal/household, trade, building, construction, manufacturing
- Contributing factors: High interest rates (16.89% average), weak internal lending policies, inadequate borrower assessment
- Economy grew 4.7% in 2024 (down from 5.7% previous year)
- Still recovering from COVID-19 effects
- CBK maintains banking industry is adequately capitalized and well-positioned

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: NPL crisis is SEVERE at 17.1%. This is the highest level since 2006. MFIs face similar pressures. Software solutions that improve credit scoring, early warning systems, collections management, and loan restructuring will be in HIGH DEMAND. Agriculture sector (20% NPL) is a key MFI target market - need sector-specific risk models.

#### DOCUMENT KE-DATA-005
**SOURCE_URL**: https://www.kba.co.ke/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/STATE-OF-THE-BANKING-INDUSTRY-REPORT-2025.pdf
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Industry Report
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2025-08

**KEY CONTENT**:
- State of Banking Industry Report 2025 by Kenya Bankers Association
- Banking sector remains well-capitalized
- Total Capital-to-Risk Weighted Assets: 19.7% (min: 14.5%)
- Core Capital-to-Risk Weighted Assets: 17.4% (min: 10.5%)
- Business Laws Amendment Act 2024: CBK now regulates non-deposit taking credit providers
- Licensed Digital Credit Providers: 52 (mid-2024) → 85 (H1 2025)
- Green Finance Taxonomy introduced 2024-25
- Climate-related disclosure frameworks being phased in
- Digital financial services: Licensed DCPs rose significantly
- Mobile wallet penetration: 100%
- 51% of businesses prefer mobile wallets over banks/SACCOs

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: The 51% preference for mobile wallets is EXISTENTIAL THREAT to traditional MFIs and SACCOs. This validates the M-Pesa data - mobile money is eating the deposit base. MFI software must treat mobile money integration as core functionality, not an add-on.

#### DOCUMENT KE-DATA-006
**SOURCE_URL**: https://saccoreview.co.ke/sacco-usage-rises-from-9-6-in-2021-to-11-7-in-2024-finaccess-surveys/
**COUNTRY**: Kenya
**CATEGORY**: Sector Data
**DOCUMENT_TYPE**: Survey Report
**CERTAINTY**: high
**DATE_OF_DOCUMENT**: 2024-12-06

**KEY CONTENT**:
- 7th Edition of 2024 FinAccess Household Survey launched December 6, 2024
- SACCO usage increased from 9.6% (2021) to 11.7% (2024)
- Financial inclusion context provided in conjunction with SASRA data
- Survey conducted to track financial access trends
- SACCOs showing modest growth in membership penetration

**STRATEGIC INSIGHT**: SACCO usage growing but slowly (9.6% to 11.7% = 2.1pp over 3 years). This is slower than mobile money growth. SACCOs need to modernize rapidly or risk losing relevance. Strong case for digital transformation investment.

---
